title: League of Legends is coming to the Unigames

replies.body:
It is really unfortunate that the actions and attitudes of a few people have ruined the future of division 2 for the masses.

Division 2 makes up over 90% of ranked players and now only these players have no way to compete with equally skilled teams from other Universities, or at least not on the same scale as OUC. 

I think the decision to completely cut division 2 now is unfair to most players and if there are plans to work out a different format for this tier we should have started working on it earlier so it would still be possible to run it alongside or a part of Uni Games. 

Just my two cents.

I understand the frustration and I agree with you that there are a lot of passionate university players that want to compete in tournaments that aren't at the pointy end of the rankings.

This is definitely something we want to do more of and there were a lot of positives that came from last semester's tournament. There is a lot of potential for more inter-university competition at all levels.

The next step to explore more of this for us is to work directly with the clubs to come up with a way to ensure a great experience for every player. We'll provide more updates as that progresses.

Back when I was in silver, UQ hosted a tournament between UNSW and UQ, which decided which university would win the 'state of origin. The tournament consisted of a knockout tournament starting from the UQ bronze vs UNSW Bronze, then UQ Bronze vs UNSW silver, then UQ silver, vs UNSW silver ect.. This tournament was a huge success in the fact that there were no cheaters or smurfs. UQ and UNSW managed to achieve this by hosting the event day as a 'Social Event' where everyone participating in the games or spectating would PHYSICALLY come in to their respective universities. Of course specators were not limited to physical attendance to watch the games, however the better experience was made by joining the crowd of supporters at the university. This required more effort to manage but created a more enjoyable and rewarding experience for everyone participating. Due to physically attending the event to play the game, the UQ LOL club was able to meet the players, assossiate them with the account they were using and make sure everything they were doing was by the rules. The words I would use to describe that event would be 'Magical', I had been given a glimpse of what it was like to play professional league of legends and I was emersed in a group of people all with similar love of league of legends. Even though the tournament was structured differently to how riotgames will structure their official tournaments, riotgames should copy the way UQ ran the authenticity and encouragement of following the rules so that a lower tier bracket can still exist in RiotGames official University Tournaments.

The year after that, I reached diamond and started to play with more serious teams in the UQ tournament scene, which I was ultimately inspired to participate in due to the previous tournament I had described. The University 'State of Origin' tournament that year was different, very different. There was no encouraged attendance to the Universrity campus to join the viewing parties or to compete in the tournament for both universities. This caused many issues and disputes between the teams. The University which we were competing against, (which I won't mention which uni it was but it was in NSW, the scum) had a player in their bronze team who was exceedingly more competent at playing his champion and manouvering his team around the map, than anyone else in his or our University teams up to the diamond teams. The NSW universities bronze team, whith their 'star' player managed to beat our UQ Bronze, Silver and gold teams only to be beaten by our platinum team. This player was 100% a smurf which is an assumption built up by the preceeding evidence and the fact that his entire match history of his account since it was created showed no stats of him playing 'shaco' or 'victor' at all or any other champion at such a high skill level before suddenly being able to perform at a platinum standard on the day. The reason this managed to pass through the 'checks' and 'gates' set in order to stop this kind of unfair situation to occur was because the universities no longer supported the in-campus attendance for participation or spectating of the events. If riot games is to organise another university championship, and is interested to include a lower tier bracket in order to cater for the other 90% of the player base's interests, they should enforce that the Universities League of Legends 'Social' clubs make it compulsory for attendance to their 'Tournament Social Event' . This not only will reduce the chance of people using alternative accounts to 0% but it also 'Socially' bonds the clubs members together which is the whole point of having a University LOL club anyway.

We definitely are looking to work more closely with clubs to create a competitive experience for the Div 2 tiers!

Supporting the clubs in hosting more on campus tournaments is definitely something we are considering.

Thanks for the feedback

I played in Div 2 in the last tournament and even the organizers found that many of the teams were smurfing and swapping people out, and I could really tell that in game that their skill level was way above ours.

I agree, that having a Division 2 is really good for the players like me who are below Plat and want to play in a tournament such as this, however, it becomes too difficult at the regional level to determine if there are people smurfing or cheating even. 

It upsets me that there is no Div 2 this time however I feel it is easier than having to deal with all of the possible cheaters and smurfers in the future.
TBH its not a big thing. Unless ther is some way of know who is a smurf and who is not is impossible. I found out that we had people in our div two who were ex challenger team players.....

hi, i was wondering of how you can enter this tournament, i know alot of people that would be thrilled if something like this came to new zealand. The previous tournaments at Armageddon have been great and have always excited me.
i hope you would take this in consideration. Thank you

The best way to get involved is to reach out to your local Uni club!

You can find a bunch of NZ universities registered here - http://promo.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/uni-clubs/#clubs

If you don't see a club for your uni, you can consider also starting up your own club.
